notes.title: Molecular Biology - Lecture 1
notes.subject: Biology
notes.summary: This lecture covers the fundamental mechanism of DNA replication. The process is semi-conservative, meaning each new strand contains one original strand. Key enzymes discussed include Helicase (unwinds DNA), Primase (adds RNA primers), DNA Polymerase (synthesizes new strands), and Ligase (joins Okazaki fragments). The distinction between leading and lagging strand synthesis was emphasized.

keyConcepts.title: Semi-conservative Model
keyConcepts.description: Each specific new DNA molecule preserves one of the original strands.

keyConcepts.title: Replication Fork
keyConcepts.description: The Y-shaped region where the parent DNA strands are being unwound.

keyConcepts.title: Okazaki Fragments
keyConcepts.description: Short sequences of DNA nucleotides which are synthesized discontinuously.

keyConcepts.title: Central Dogma
keyConcepts.description: Flow of genetic information from DNA to RNA to Protein.

transcript.text: All right, let's get started. Today we're diving into Chapter 12.
Remember, the directionality is crucial. Polymerase only works 5 prime to 3 prime.
If you look at the diagram, notice how the lagging strand loops out.
The semi-conservative model was proven by Meselson and Stahl in 1958.
Now let's talk about the enzymes. Helicase is the first one to act.

notes.title: Molecular Biology - Lecture 2
notes.subject: Biology
notes.summary: This lecture explores protein synthesis through transcription and translation. Transcription occurs in the nucleus where mRNA is created from DNA template. Translation happens at ribosomes where tRNA brings amino acids to build polypeptide chains.

keyConcepts.title: Transcription
keyConcepts.description: The process of copying DNA into messenger RNA.

keyConcepts.title: Translation
keyConcepts.description: The process of decoding mRNA to build a polypeptide chain.

keyConcepts.title: Codon
keyConcepts.description: A sequence of three nucleotides that codes for an amino acid.

keyConcepts.title: Ribosome
keyConcepts.description: The cellular machinery responsible for protein synthesis.

transcript.text: Today we continue with the central dogma - from DNA to protein.
RNA polymerase binds to the promoter region to begin transcription.

notes.title: Intro to Psychology - Memory
notes.subject: Psychology
notes.summary: Overview of human memory systems including sensory memory, short-term (working) memory, and long-term memory. Discussion of encoding, storage, and retrieval processes. Key concepts include chunking, elaborative rehearsal, and the serial position effect.

keyConcepts.title: Working Memory
keyConcepts.description: A limited-capacity system for temporary storage and manipulation of information.

keyConcepts.title: Long-term Potentiation
keyConcepts.description: The strengthening of synapses that contributes to memory formation.

keyConcepts.title: Encoding Specificity
keyConcepts.description: Memory retrieval is most effective when context matches encoding conditions.

keyConcepts.title: Chunking
keyConcepts.description: Grouping information into meaningful units to enhance memory capacity.

notes.title: Microeconomics - Supply and Demand
notes.subject: Economics
notes.summary: Fundamental concepts of supply and demand curves, market equilibrium, and price mechanisms. Covers shifts vs movements along curves, elasticity basics, and real-world applications.

keyConcepts.title: Law of Demand
keyConcepts.description: As price increases, quantity demanded decreases, ceteris paribus.

keyConcepts.title: Law of Supply
keyConcepts.description: As price increases, quantity supplied increases, ceteris paribus.

keyConcepts.title: Market Equilibrium
keyConcepts.description: The point where supply equals demand, determining market price.

keyConcepts.title: Price Elasticity
keyConcepts.description: Measure of responsiveness of quantity to price changes.

notes.title: Calculus I - Limits and Continuity
notes.subject: Mathematics
notes.summary: Introduction to limits, including one-sided limits, infinite limits, and limits at infinity. Definition of continuity and types of discontinuities. Techniques for evaluating limits algebraically.

keyConcepts.title: Limit Definition
keyConcepts.description: The value a function approaches as input approaches a certain value.

keyConcepts.title: Continuity
keyConcepts.description: A function is continuous if the limit equals the function value at that point.

keyConcepts.title: L'Hôpital's Rule
keyConcepts.description: A method for evaluating limits of indeterminate forms.

notes.title: Spanish 101 - Common Phrases
notes.subject: Languages
notes.summary: Essential Spanish phrases for everyday conversation. Greetings, introductions, asking for directions, ordering food, and polite expressions.

keyConcepts.title: Formal vs Informal
keyConcepts.description: Using 'usted' for formal and 'tú' for informal address.

keyConcepts.title: Gender Agreement
keyConcepts.description: Adjectives must match the gender of the noun they modify.

notes.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
notes.subject: Computer Science
notes.summary: Introduction to AI covers the history and evolution of artificial intelligence, from the Turing Test to modern Deep Learning. Key topics include the difference between Narrow AI and General AI, the importance of data, and ethical considerations.

keyConcepts.title: Turing Test
keyConcepts.description: A test of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human.

keyConcepts.title: Narrow AI vs General AI
keyConcepts.description: Narrow AI is designed for specific tasks (like chess), while General AI would have human-like cognitive abilities across domains.

keyConcepts.title: Machine Learning
keyConcepts.description: A subset of AI that involves training algorithms to learn from data and improve over time.

transcript.text: Welcome to CS 101. Today we're discussing the basics of Artificial Intelligence.
It all started with Alan Turing and his famous question: 'Can machines think?'

cards.front: What is the function of Helicase?
cards.back: Helicase unzips the DNA double helix by breaking the hydrogen bonds between base pairs.
A mode of replication where new double helices contain one original strand and one newly synthesized strand.

cards.front: Which direction does DNA synthesis occur?
cards.back: 5' to 3' direction.
Short sequences of DNA nucleotides synthesized discontinuously on the lagging strand.

cards.front: What is the role of DNA Primase?
cards.back: Primase synthesizes short RNA primers that provide a starting point for DNA polymerase.
Ligase joins Okazaki fragments together by forming phosphodiester bonds.
The Y-shaped region where the parent DNA strands are being unwound and replicated.
The strand synthesized continuously in the 5' to 3' direction toward the replication fork.
The strand synthesized discontinuously in short segments away from the replication fork.
Meselson and Stahl in 1958 using density gradient centrifugation.

cards.front: What is the origin of replication?
cards.back: A specific sequence where DNA replication begins.
An enzyme that extends telomeres to prevent chromosome shortening during replication.
A syntax extension for JavaScript that allows writing HTML-like code in React components.
A reusable piece of UI that can accept inputs (props) and return React elements.
A React Hook that lets you add state to functional components.
A Hook for performing side effects in functional components, like data fetching or subscriptions.
Short for properties - read-only data passed from parent to child components.
A lightweight copy of the real DOM that React uses to optimize rendering performance.

cards.front: When did World War I begin?
cards.back: 1914, triggered by the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand.
A cultural movement from 14th-17th century emphasizing art, science, and humanism.

cards.front: What was the Treaty of Versailles?
cards.back: The 1919 peace treaty that ended WWI and imposed harsh penalties on Germany.
A specific group of atoms within molecules that determines the characteristic chemical reactions.
A saturated hydrocarbon with only single bonds between carbon atoms.
A property where a molecule cannot be superimposed on its mirror image.
Hola
Gracias
Por favor
¿Dónde está...?
Me gustaría...

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Law of Demand?
options: As price increases, quantity demanded increases.
As price increases, quantity demanded decreases.
Demand is determined solely by supply.
Price has no effect on demand.
questions.explanation: The Law of Demand states that, ceteris paribus, as the price of a good increases, the quantity demanded decreases.

options: The monetary cost of a good.
The value of the next best alternative accepted.
The value of the next best alternative foregone.
A cost that cannot be recovered.
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of what you give up when making a choice - the next best alternative foregone.
At equilibrium, the quantity that producers want to sell equals the quantity consumers want to buy.

questions.text: A shift in the demand curve is caused by:
options: A change in the price of the good
A change in consumer income or preferences
questions.explanation: Shifts in demand are caused by non-price factors like income, preferences, or prices of related goods.

questions.text: What is the capacity of short-term memory?
questions.explanation: George Miller's research showed short-term memory holds about 7 (±2) chunks of information.

questions.text: Which type of memory is most affected in amnesia patients?
questions.explanation: Episodic memory (personal experiences) is typically most affected in amnesia.

options: Connecting new information to existing knowledge
questions.explanation: Elaborative rehearsal involves making meaningful connections to better encode information into long-term memory.
Factor to get (x+2)(x-2)/(x-2) = x+2. At x=2, this equals 4.

questions.text: A function is continuous at x=a if:
options: f(a) is defined, limit exists, and they are equal
questions.explanation: Continuity requires all three conditions: f(a) defined, limit exists, and lim f(x) = f(a).

questions.text: Which enzyme unwinds the DNA double helix?
questions.explanation: Helicase breaks hydrogen bonds between base pairs to unwind the double helix.
Each new DNA molecule contains one original strand and one newly synthesized strand.
